comments.commentBody: The NYC Building Code requires carbon monoxide and smoke detectors in the building and Local Law #7 have maintenance requirements as well as gas leakage safety and prevention. I do understand not all CO detectors will detect gas leak, but some models do. Also, it is easy to put the blame on ConEd but we don't know if any of the tenant informed the superintendent about the gas odor or if the superintendent informed the building management. It doesn't make sense to me to wait a whole day before calling anyone about a gas leak, this is crazy. The public, as well as landlords, should be better educated to prevent tragedies like this.

I do not see the Bitcoin future, I see it more as a strategy of deterrence to the growing threat of Chinese currency, which in future will predominate in the market displacing the dollar. (http://mundobags.co/3_nike )
Bitcoin as a currency that has no speculative trading, there is very strong, the owners of the financial system and not leave so easily lose their profits.
Just so sad. My youngest daughter until quite recently lived about three blocks from here. Lots of old infrastructure buried in the storied city of New York.
I checked the figures online.  About 25 people die each year from gas explosions.  That's half the number who die from lightning strikes.
I believe that the people smelled the gas the night before but did not report it until the following morning.

It is amazing how many people perished all over the country because of explosions caused by gas leaks. This last incident seems to be relatively minor compared to the previous ones reported from elsewhere.

Pipes - water and gas - are bursting all over the country, not everyday but often enough. Isn't there some predictability to all this? Pipes have a limited lifespan. Do we know what it is on the average? Should not the utility companies know? Perhaps, they do not - they may not have even records available.

Apparently, people in that building smelled gas a night before and reported it to th Con Edison. And then they just opened a window to get the smell out from their apartments...

It is natural that some kind of litigation may follow but what would it accomplish? Lives were lost and it was, perhaps, not necessary.

New York is an old city - and while it's constantly changing - especially with new high-rise construction expanding to previously low-rise neighborhoods - many of the buildings here are very old.

And by old, I mean a 100-150 years old or more - but old does NOT mean decrepit or "out-of-repair and substandard."

Many of these old buildings are the classic apartment houses and townhouses that are architectural gems - the most coveted, valued properties in the city.

Other old buildings - like the one I live in - are far from chic, but still well-maintained and in solid condition. Many such buildings - especially in lower-income neighborhoods - are owned by landlords who also live in the buildings. There are millions of tenants in these buildings in NY - including middle- and lower-income people who can't afford to move.

Are you suggesting razing entire blocks and neighborhoods of older, low-rise buildings and replacing them with shiny new high-rises? Well, that was tried in the mid-20th century - and the results were disastrous, with soulless high-rise towers destroying the neighborliness of the old human-scale housing.

Of course, today, most of the new high-rises are luxury towers built for the very wealthy - no non-multi-millionaires need apply. As more of those go up, more and more of us middle- & lower-income people get pushed out.

It's not all about the age of the buildings - it's the loss of funding for and neglect of our infrastructure.
Need not go to a Brazillian favela. Look no further than a favela in the USA. Easy to find.

Pretty rich, a son of a big construction company owner lecturing on the evils of feeding children.  I doubt very much that Mr. Ryan (or his sidekick Rand "food stamps are servitude" Paul, son of a successful physician) ever missed an important meal.  It's pretty clear these guys don't have a clue of what it feels like to not have enough to eat, and not know when or where the next meal might come. Let's drop them in a Brazilian favela with no money, no phone, no ID.  After a couple of days of not much vittles and trying to sleep in a doorway, I'm betting that the possibility of a full stomach would chase away a lot of Ayn Randian "soul".
This is a sad old argument. The government can be all intrusive and it shouldn't bother anyone, and if you are bothered you are probably guilty. What countries operate this way? Hopefully not ours.

Apparently, no one is listening to the full #feinstein speech on the floor -- dismissing a most qualified speech concerning a congressional committees perseverance to declassify the evidence of a dark program and substituting instead the word 'hypocrite'. This is an issue of higher cardinality than the NSA spying on me as a u.s. citizen (as much as such spying does deeply trouble me, it is a separate and equally important issue). Stop cluttering the dialogue and significance of #feinstein speech on the Senate floor. 'Hypocrite' or not... the current stance of the Senator is one of importance and which ALL Americans should support -- Real congressional oversight of the executive branch.

in the end republicans in congress only care about power and not the people or gov't for the people...........

"But virtually none of this really benefits the working or middle classes except at the margins".......What a bunch of total garbage. Last time I checked the Obama approach to unemployment was to raise taxes to pay to improve the infrastructure - repair highways and bridges, modernize the power grid, improve national parks, develop high speed rail, upgrade the public schools, make college more affordable, fund scientific research. When the labor force is more fully employed the wages will go up across the board (supply and demand).  And yes, taxing the affluent to improve the infrastructure is a form of redistribution of wealth, but when corporations send U.S. jobs overseas it is also a redistribution of wealth in the opposite direction; and the virtue of the Obama proposal is when you improve the infrastructure everybody benefits regardless of their economic status. Of course Republicans oppose raising taxes to improve the infra structure.....because they are basically dumb. Sometimes I think Republicans really want to live in a third world country, because they seem to be hell bent on creating it right here at home.

Well, we can regulate what is on our own tables and send a message.
If one eats less, yet sustainable, good tasting food, it costs close to
what the supermarket proffers. I agree about regulation, but it is also
up to the consumer. I do concede that current work schedules, both parents at jobs to provide what a single earner could achieve when I
grew up, make it tempting to buy ready cooked junk.

Secretary Kerry has drawn a connection between global warming and WMD, but my email to the State Department on connections between tar sand imports and the Chemical Weapons Convention is still unanswered.   Schedule 3 chemicals that may be involved in tar sand production include triethanolamine, ethyl diethanolamine and methyl diethanolamine but State has not indicated that it has carried out any review of the pipeline under the Chemical Weapons Convention.

We'll see if this this is all just talk or actually means something when, shortly after the elections, Kerry/Obama approve or reject the Keystone pipeline.

(BTW: Transcanada, the company that wants to build this infernal machine, named it "Keystone" because they see it as the key to their tar shipping system and to the success of their whole operation — despite all the blather about how it doesn't matter that much if it's built or not. If it doesn't matter, why is Transcanada pushing it so hard?)

The great thing about food is that most people react quickly to any suspicion that it is tainted, it is probably some kind of evolutionary survival mechanism.

As we saw recently, once parents learned that schools were serving their children "pink slime" (beef by-products treated with ammonia), an almost universal practice disappeared from schools almost overnight.

Likewise, we should all understand that the increase in virulent and drug resistant strains of E Coli and Salmonella Heidelberg in beef and chicken are a direct consequence of crowding, feeding and routine antibiotic practices.

Knowledge like this makes the choice at the supermarket a lot easier. If the price is a little higher, just eat a little less meat and throw in more vegetables. Significant movement in consumer preferences can change what government regulations cannot.

Talk to your family, friends, neighbors, anyone you can about the "gross" factor in factory farmed meat. Trigger those evolutionary protective mechanisms.

The president does not have the power of the purse.  The money has to be transferred along with the drone program.  He specifically requested that be done last Fall when they prepared the Budget and the Appropriators did that.  It was reversed while the Budget worked its way thru Congress.  It was reported in the Beltway papers.  Google

cat48,
The power of the purse is a weak defense for Obama's drone program. Think, of the recent executive orders that Obama has used of late...they all came with a price.

Tim McCoy,

What you seem to be saying is that Obama has a right to legally kill someone because he believes he has the moral authority to do so because of a perceived threat to us.

Isn't that what the now new recruits of terrorism are now thinking?

It is hogwash to say that President Obama's reform of the drone program is being stalled by Congressional opposition and bureaucratic inertia.

By presidential executive orders, Mr. Obama has virtually ignored the constitution in almost every other domestic issue that he does not like.

President Obama does not get a pass on this one...he can end the drone strikes with his pen and his phone.

There is no justification in the killing of anyone that is suspected of terrorist ties...we are not the arbitrator of who lives and who dies.

Hi KJ
I'm childless, but not childfree. As an active aunt, godmother and educator, I am very interested in a parenting issues and so I read this blog to see what's going on with parents and how people deal with various issues. I enjoy most of the posts.

I would love to see less navel gazing, less NYC and some more on policy, additional focus on other parts of the country, expecially urban vs suburban, vs rural and in betweens. I would also like to see some more posts on bringing up children with a sense of morality/spirituality.
I really enjoyed the posts on how parents balanced their responsibilities between work and home.

I look forward to all the changes. Best of luck and thank you.

25A The 2000 Richard Gere film where he plays a Gynecologist, I personally feel should have been titled DRG, instead of DRT, because the former would've been definitely more Spot-On! Wink Wink

Howie

Any lunch I might pack for my 10th-grade daughter is likely to be:
1. Forgotten
2. Unable to fit in an overloaded backpack
3. Smooshed if it does fit
4. At room temperature for a distressingly long time
5. Boring because it looks like last night's leftovers.

My daughter's arts high school handled the school lunch issue nicely. It set up a culinary conservatory that trains students professionally after school in food preparation. The students now make the school lunches, and my daughter raves about the food.

Wonderful piece. This is something I think about often.

I'm raising 3 kids in the Midwest, and my brother is raising one daughter in New York City. It's fascinating to compare the differences in how we parent and what choices we have based on where we live. The most fundamental is probably the fact that I've never heard anyone in the Midwest decide not to have more children based on space. You can always find space here. But I know several parents in New York for whom space is an important consideration when planning a family. The ways in which our kids are independent is vastly different as well. My niece is far more savvy than my own children when it comes to public transit and restaurants, but compared to my kids she's on a much shorter leash and is amazed at the more free range lifestyle of her cousins when she comes to visit.

First, gas is much cheaper than electricity. If you use your stove every day - especially if you cook most of your meals - your electric bill would be higher.

Second, with more devices and appliances in our homes, we use much more electricity overall - is it really a good idea to add another?

Third, most people prefer gas for cooking - you don't have to wait for coils to heat or cool, so it's quick & easy to adjust the temperature.

And as Patsy47 points out, a gas stove still works during a power failure.

Plus, there seem to be far more electric fires than gas explosions.

Posey,

With declining wages and rising prices for meat of all types, it is difficult for many more to be picky about what they buy, raw or pre-cooked. It takes money and effort to avoid meats that are unhealthy.

The conclusion presented in the next to the last paragraph of this column is wrong. The idea that we must either have inefficient, old fashioned family farms or industrialized, dehumanized, even savage, treatment of animals misstates the case.

SOME of the innovations of the last 80 yrs. in farming are good. Larger operations bring more production at lower cost, for example, than those that could be mounted by a single family (mom, dad and hard working kids). The choice isn't between a tiny, hand to mouth farm and a huge agri-business model.

The lone farmer and the agrarian society ideal from Jefferson's time could not endure. The farmer was often out of touch with modern methods and determined to stay that way. He lacked the capital necessary to change quickly and was at the complete mercy of the weather, diseases and huge market swings.

What we have now, however, is a looming disaster. Not only are chickens pumped full of drugs, they are raised in near total darkness to keep them eating around the clock. Sure, the meat produced is greater per bird, but it is often tough, barely edible. As long as people buy it, the machine will keep running ever faster.

From what I have seen and read, I am left to conclude that our food supply has been hijacked by people who give no thought and care not one whit about our health. We have a perfect situation: they get rich, we get poisoned. We are being slowly killed by food not fit for human consumption.

Sorry, I was trying to reply to the comment above, so my first comment probably does not make sense! However, I also agree with your comment. I have found it a little baffling that someone who lost his father in a sudden and traumatic way would then go through life feeling so little compassion for others!

I don't know what happened to Paul Ryan when he was a kid but it must have done some psychological damage. Here is a guy whose idea of fun is fisting large carp in a mud hole (a psychoanalyst would have a field day with this) and whose political impulses include stealing lunches from kids and money from old people.

No wonder he is a darling of the Right.

I thought that at least one of the reasons for free lunches was to make certain that no child was malnourished. Recent reports indicate that far too many children in this country go hungry.

But beginning at least width Reagan, Republicans has assured us that the problems of the poor need not concern us.
I believe one of the first things Boeing did was send experts to Malaysia to assist in the investigation.

The longer the search takes to find the missing plane or any wreckage of it, the more it highlights the limitations of our technology. But it also raises hopes of finding the passengers alive.  I pray for the latter and hope this impels us to globally review our current aviation policies and apparatus.
